Raising, not for the first time, questions about how many houses Purplebricks actually sells.

wayneJ Just think of the possibilities the PurpleBricks style of measurement offers......an indebted company such as Capita could put its debt on a 'ignore for reporting purposes break'
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Completely agree with your opinion on cryptos BE. Maybe there is a consensus forming?
Shinshin PURP - Funny how the best run businesses never comment on short term moves or analyst reports and just let their results tell the story
BE11:13am

And also making some cautious observations about accounting that might be at the top of some investors' minds post Capita.

Miss Piggy @waynej: trend following trading strategy would say you need to sell losing stocks.
BE11:13am

Let me whack up the summary.

11:13 am
BE11:14am

Purplebricks (PB) does not disclose how many home it sells. Our research sample found that it had sold 51.6% of the homes listed in November 2016 within 10 months, a similar success rate to the overall market, but below the company's claim of 88%. Unlike the traditional market, those who don't sell still have to pay PB's fees. PB's latest results reported that its average revenue per UK customer was £1,138.

An impressive disruptor. We admire the speed at which PB has grown and the sheer scale of its ambition, from recording its first revenues in FY14 to disrupting the estate agency markets in three continents by FY17. No one can doubt that it has disrupted the markets in which it operates and we can see the attractions of the revenue growth from its upfront fixed-fee model.

The £1,000 coin toss. We found that 51.6% of those who instructed PB to sell their home in November 2016 had sold their home within 10 months. These odds are finely balanced, but with around £1,000 at stake it is a close call for homeowners who will pay the fixed fees whether or not they sell their home.

Lefevre I could understand purple bricks working in a buoyant housing market - like the Blair bubble years - but selling houses is tough now
BE11:14am

Why is this important? In a Radio 4 interview in October 2016, PB’s CEO, Michael Bruce, is on record as saying that the company sells 88% of homes within 10 months and that it sells more houses as a percentage of those taken to market than any other agent in the UK.

Similar to the market as a whole. We have benchmarked PB's performance over the last 14 months against the performance of more than 7,000 different estate agency brands in the UK. Our analysis suggests that PB's success rate is near the middle of the pack. However, although only just over half actually sell their home, everyone has to pay. With a traditional high street agent, the homeowner only pays if the agent sells their home.

Devil in the detail. A review of PB's accounting policies raises concerns to us that either its contractual obligations to its customers end with their home being listed on the major property portals or that revenue may have been overstated and deferred income provisions understated in its audited accounts.

Valuation/Risks
Valuation. At 490p, PB trades on a CY2018 PER of 131x against the sector trading on 13x and an EV/EBITDA of 94x (sector 8x). Risks. Should the model stumble, the share price may do likewise. Upside risks to our thesis include higher growth in fees, instructions and LPEs than we assume.

Forester Shinshin - the best managers should not give a monkeys about short term SP movements - after all it has no impact on their day job!
wayneJ @BE - the very comment 'how many houses Purplebricks actually sells' is very interesting for another reason - do people sign up with Purplebricks and give up - then sell elsewhere......does PURP count those sales?
mb Selling 52% of your listing isn't actually that bad - it's about what a lot of traditional agents manage, but PB can't say that as it would be a bad marketing message.
Pharma Do any estate agency chains report proportions of houses sold? When I looked up houses I viewed last year, to see what they sold at, around half the sellers seem to have given up (and we didn't look at any Purple Bricks marketed houses).
BE11:15am

That's referring to Michael
Bruce on Radio 4's Moneybox, on 17 October 2016

11:15 am
BE11:15am

As per transcript:

BE11:15am

Michael Bruce: 88% of people sell their house prior to getting to the period of deferment,
which is 10 months. At the end of the day, we sell more houses as a percentage of what
we take to the market than any other agent in the UK. We’re also the most positively
reviewed agent than anyone else in the UK, and that’s because we have a strong
reputation for selling houses and getting the job done better than anyone else.
Radio 4 presenter: So 88% of the people who list with you sell their home?
Michael Bruce: Correct.
Radio 4 presenter: So 12% don’t. So they’re the ones who in a sense are subsidising them
because they pay what’s now £849 and don’t actually get a sale.
Michael Bruce: What I said was 88% of people actually sell their house prior to the 10-
month period. What I didn’t say was 12% don’t sell. Those people will remain on the
market, and stay on the market until they sell their house.

SupposeToBeWorking... How many of that 52% sold gave up on purple Bricks and sold via a different agent?
Pseudonym I suppose that if you get paid regardless of whether the house sells then PB is actually selling adverts.

Pseudonym I'm not sure any advertiser actually says how many widgets were bought because of their adverts..
Rick Chasey In my instance, the house i bought is listed 10% higher than the price I bought it at.

Blank canvas morning
BE11:21am

We therefore think it fair to assume that ‘conversion from instruction to sale’ implies that a home was actually sold. If what Purplebricks meant was ‘conversion from instruction to sale agreed’, we believe it would have said that. Annual reports often contain footnotes to help explain accounting terms and where nonstandard
definitions are used. For instance, on page 6 of Purplebricks’ Annual Report, a footnote defines Adjusted EBITDA as ‘the loss from operating activities excluding amortisation of intangibles, share based payment charges, fundraising costs, fair values on
derivatives and depreciation.’
There is no footnote to the phrase ‘conversion from instruction to sale was 83%’ explaining that properties withdrawn from the market and/or on marketing breaks have been excluded from the calculation. In our view, therefore, most, including ourselves, would understand the phrase ‘conversion from instruction to sale was 83%’ to mean that in the accounting period 83% of instructions ended in the legal sale of the customer’s property.

Pharma @Mb, yes, because they were badgered into it. Now I'd like to see the same numbers from Countrywide etc. (the Jefferies chart doesn't seem to cover traditional estate agents)

BE11:25am

FY2013-FY2016
 Fees earned on instructions of residential property are accounted for at the point
of publication of the advert to property portals. Where property particulars have not yet been published to property portals, the fees are recognised as deferred income and presented within liabilities.
FY2017
 Fees earned on instruction of residential property are accounted for over time as
the Group’s obligations are completed. Where the Group’s obligations have not been completed fees are recorded as deferred income and presented within liabilities.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

As Jefferies says:

BE11:25am

Is this a change in policy or just a change in wording? Given that in the FY2017 audited
accounts the comparative FY2016 Deferred Income balance has not been restated from
the audited FY2016 accounts, it appears to us that the policy hasn’t changed. This leads
us to conclude that the group believes that its contractual obligations have been met
when a customer’s home has been listed on a portal rather than actually being sold.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

If our interpretation of the accounting policy is correct, it might be inappropriate for
Purplebricks to lead in the UK with a marketing message that they are ‘Proper Estate
Agents’ rather than just offering a service to list properties on the property portals.
If our interpretation is incorrect and Purplebricks does indeed have an ongoing and openended
‘Proper Estate Agent’ obligation to its customers, it may have overstated revenue in
its audited accounts and understated its deferred income liabilities. Revenue may have
been recognised too early and potentially insufficient allowance made for the future costs
relating to providing estate agency services to customers who have withdrawn properties
and for those currently taking a marketing break.

BE11:28am

Response to research. Jefferies issued a research note yesterday, which suggests that from a sample of homes that Purplebricks listed in the UK in November 2016, c52% have since been sold. Purplebricks refute the findings as the research does not take into account properties that have exchanged, have reached sold
subject to contract (SSTC), or are on marketing breaks. Furthermore, it also may not include properties that have completed but have yet to be uploaded to the Land Registry, which can take several months. In sum, these could account for
an additional 25-30% of sales. Indeed, Purplebricks reiterates its most recently published sales conversion rate from instruction to sale agreed of 78%. In today’s trading update, Purplebricks has announced that the number of sales agreed in the UK in January 2018 was 4,618. This compares to an average number of monthly listings over the last 10 months of c5,000. On this basis, the proportion of instructions to sales agreed is c92%. While inevitably a small number of sales agreed will not proceed to a legal completion, we do not believe the number will fall to anywhere near the 52% referred to in the Jefferies note.

Last month, Brookfield was left weighing its options after a second takeover offer for London-listed IWG was rebuffed just three days before the UK takeover deadline. That bid valued IWG at £2.5bn.

Brookfield and Onex subsequently increased their offer to 300p a share but that was rejected, said two people familiar with the situation.

The groups had until Friday to agree a deal under the UK takeover code after being granted permission to extend their talks.

One person familiar with the situation said IWG’s largest shareholder and founder Mark Dixon was inclined to sell the company while other directors were minded to resist Brookfield and Onex’s advances.

Numis:

11:39 am
BE11:40am

The withdrawal of a potential bid by the Brookfield / Onex consortium places the focus back on the trading dynamics of the business. As expected, the mature portfolio returned to growth in Q4, assisted by some weak comparatives, and the FY Group trading performance is in-line with expectations. However, in our view, competitive pressures and the capital intensity of the business are increasing, and there is much to prove over the next 12 months

BE11:40am

And Peel Hunt.

Swedish Chef Sold flat in London recently and looking for good home for proceeds. Know any ‘star’ fund managers. The sort that thinks capita & purplebricks are good bets?
BE11:41am

We don’t see anybody else paying up for IWG so the investment case turns back to the fundamentals. According to the trading statement these are improving, but the numbers are much too inconclusive for us, even if management’s tone is upbeat. Still, the direction of travel is forward and on 15x FY18E (12x “mature” EPS) the stock hardly looks expensive. We stick with our fair value of 240p for now and target a share price in line with that.

red @rwl its interesting because high freq not involved on futs excahnges. far too few contracts have changed hands. too little liquidity for them. which tells its own story.
SupposeToBeWorking... @SwedishChef What are your thoughts about cold fusion? I might know just the man
11:41 am
BE11:41am

We thought that Mark Dixon and the Board would take 320-340p, albeit a discount to his earlier partial sale. Media commentary suggested a 280-300p offer. If we are right, then it will be difficult for the shares to trade above 220-240p in our view for a while (which would give 30% upside to a bid price, and is close to our 240p fair value) until business performance clearly improves. An accompanying trading update sees FY17 profit in line with consensus, but this is not yet compelling.

The failure of discussions with Brookfield's highlights that management remain confident of the medium-term value creation potential of the business. Trading in 4Q17 has improved markedly and the group looks set to step-up capex investment in 2018. We continue to view IWG as well placed to benefit from the ongoing secular change in the flexible workspace market - Buy.

Lefevre I think PB valuation only makes sense if it manages (through advertising) to become synonymous with selling a house - as Amazon has done with buying books online. The danger is that it ends up becoming best known for controversy over it's advertising claims

Our target price of 274p is set by our DCF model, which uses a 13% cost of capital, models growth fading to the perpetuity growth rate of 1% in 2030

3Q Group revenue was £5,979m, down -1.5% on an underlying ex transit basis (same rate as 2Q), with revenue -1.5% below consensus of £6,068m. EBITDA of £1,826m was -0.7% below consensus of £1,838m. Nomalised FCF was £702m, 26% ahead of consensus of £556m but driven by working capital. BT considering alternatives to a cash top of pension scheme.

BE11:47am

Details:

Consumer: Revenue flat yoy driven by growth of BT mobile offset by voice line. EBITDA down 4%. Broadband net adds of +35k (vs +83k in 3Q17 and +22k in 2Q18) gives BT a 22% share of DSL net adds (down from 34% in 2Q). Fibre net adds of +208K (vs +211k 3Q17 and +179k in 2Q18). TV subs -5k (vs +52k in 3Q 17).
EE: Revenue up +4% but EBITDA down 6% due to handset upfront costs (iPhone) with postpaid revenue +6% and fixed broadband revenue +14%, prepaid -15%. Postpaid +235k net adds (vs +276k in 3Q17 and +279k in 2Q18) with churn of 1.2% (static and low). Geographic reach now at 90%, appears on target for 95% coverage by Dec 2020.
Business & Public Sector: Revenue down 5% driven by fixed voice and lower equipment sales, offset by growth in mobile and networking. SME down 3%, Corporate revenue down 7%, Public Sector & Major Business revenue down 6%. Order intake down 22% in Quarter but up 12% on rolling 12m basis.
Global Services: Revenue down 9% incl -£18m currency and -£42m (almost zero margin) transit. Underlying down 6% reflecting lower IP Exchange volume and continued in-sourcing of US contract (announced several quarters ago). By region, UK -8%, Continental Europe -1%, US -9%. Order intake -11% in quarter and -25% on 12m rolling basis. EBITDA up 257% due to Italy in comparative.
Wholesale: Revenue down 4% with managed solutions down 8% due to lower 4G build programmes (reaching maturity) offset by ventures business +9%
Openreach: Revenue flat, EBITDA down 5% due to business rates. Fibre broadband now passing 27.4m premises with 886k ‘ultrafast’ (ie either G.Fast or FTTP) up from 770k at 2Q18.
Pension: IAS 19 net deficit £7.9bn vs £7.7bn at Sept. BT says it is ‘considering a number of funding options .. including arrangements that would give the BTPS a prior claim over certain BT assets’. We take this to be a discussion about an asset top up as discussed in our earlier note (BT Pension deficit could surprise!, October 2017)

BE11:55am

Despite the strong quarter and above consensus revenue guidance, 2018 Core EPS guidance may disappoint some investors. We anticipated the increase in SG&A associated with the launch of several new drugs in our recent report ( AstraZeneca PLC (AZN.L): Farxiga Boosts World’s Fastest Growing Major Pharma. BUY Jan-18) but it appears we may have under-appreciated the near-term negative impact on gross margin, associated with launch of biologics Imfinzi and Fasenra, on top of LOE for mature products. Despite this, we view the revenue outlook as key however. Profitability from both COGS and OPEX will follow, assuming revenue meets or exceeds our expectations. We underline our confidence in AZN’s c.20% LT Core EPS CAGR outlook (ex externalisation revenues) given the breadth and depth of its small and large molecule pipeline. It remains our global preferred name in the sector. We prefer BUY-rated Bayer in EU. We prefer BUY-rated LLY, BMY and MRK among the US majors.

11:55 am
BE11:55am

What's New? — AZN reported a strong quarter with notable beats in diabetes (Onglyza, Farxiga), respiratory and Tagrisso leading to a 5% revenue beat. The 62% EPS beat versus consensus for the quarter reflected the contribution from lower R&D (post MRK deal) and a significant contribution from other operating income. AZN reported Core EPS of $1.30 compared with Citi 4Q estimate of $1.17. Guidance for 2018 revenue is slightly ahead of consensus, but the mid-point of EPS guidance ($3.35) is 4% below consensus expectations.

 Implications — Market should overlook near-term margin pressure in 2018, and focus on new products’ revenue opportunities..

The consensus looks for a 180K rise in non-farm payrolls and a 0.2% MoM rise in average hourly earnings. HSBC economics is marginally below consensus on both parameters (170K and 0.1% MoM). Colder weather and seasonal quirks offer downside risks to the data and any ‘miss’ on the data could be dismissed by the market as a result, although the market appetite for bad news on the USD offers a counter-argument to this suggested indifference. Any upbeat surprise would point to a stronger USD but as noted above, we think the impact would be fleeting.

12:01 pm
BE12:02pm

The failure of yields to drive FX currently suggests today’s US employment report should have little lasting impact on the USD. While the knee-jerk response to the headlines will likely be conventional, with any hawkish signal being USD positive for example, it is questionable whether the data can have a lasting effect. After all, the main driver to USD weakness so far in 2018 has not been cyclical as US rate expectations have risen more swiftly than elsewhere in G10. USD weakness is structural, reflecting the new focus on the US trade balance and the administration’s appetite for USD weakness, at least in the short-term. This shift in personality of the FX market means it is hard for the data to drive the market beyond the initial headline reaction. In addition, the USD negative implications of a focus on the structural means markets seem more willing to react to any cyclical data that is weak and therefore aligns with the structural bias than to hawkish data that challenges it.
